tmpls.name: IO Card

fields: Bone serves as a storage site for {{c1::calcium}} and {{c1::phosphate}}, and for proteins and growth factors
Bone is a typical {{c1::connective}} tissue, consisting of {{c2::cells}} and {{c2::extracellular matrix}}

Region of the Long bones 
{{c1::diaphysis}}
•shaft
{{c2::epiphysis}}
•articular end of bone
{{c3::epiphyseal plate/disc}}
•growth region between diaphysis and epiphysis
{{c4::metaphysis}}
•transitional area between diaphysis and epiphyseal plate

Organic component of bone
•constitutes about 35% of dry weight of bone
•type {{c1::I}} collagen fibers
accounts for 80-90% of organic component of bone matrix
•{{c3::GAGs (glycoaminoglycans)}}
esp. {{c4::chondroitin}} sulfate and {{c4::keratan}} sulfate
•{{c2::glycoproteins}}
Osteocalcin, osteonectin, osteopontin, bone sialoprotein, etc

Inorganic component of bone: 
•accounts for ~ 65% of dry weight of bone
•{{c1::hydroxyapatite}} [Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2] – a type of calcium phosphate
•{{c2::HCO3-, citrate, Mg++, Na+, K+}}
can substitute for components of hydroxyapatite

{{c1::Osteogenic (osteoprogenitor)}} cells
•found in the deepest layer of {{c2::periosteum}}, and adjacent to the {{c2::endosteum}}
•derive from {{c3::mesenchyme}}
•undergo cell division to give rise to {{c4::osteoblasts}}
•(might also differentiate into {{c4::chondrogenic}} cells)

{{c2::Osteoblasts}}
•found both on the {{c1::periosteal}} and {{c1::endosteal}} surfaces of bone
•{{c3::basophilic::type of staining}}, due to large amount of {{c6::rER}}, {{c6::large Golgi apparatus}} (stains light)
•communicate by {{c4::gap}} junctions
•role
a)secrete the bone matrix
organic component – {{c5::osteoid}}
mineralization
b)signaling

{{c1::Osteocytes}}  
•once an osteoblast surrounds itself with matrix, it becomes an {{c1::osteocyte}}
•located in a {{c2::lacuna}}* within bone matrix
•little {{c3::RER::cell organelle}} or {{c3::Golgi::cell organelle}}
•osteocyte processes extend in canaliculi
•processes of adjacent cells connected by {{c4::gap}} junctions
•roles:
{{c5::
maintain bone matrix
}}{{c5::mechanotransduction}}

{{c1::osteoclasts::bone cell}}
•large multinucleate cells
•form resorption (Howship’s) lacunae on bone surfaces
•attach to bone by {{c2::sealing zone (“clear zone”)}}, which surrounds a {{c3::ruffled border}}
•contains abundant {{c4::mitochondria and lysosomes, Golgi and RER, and vesicles::cell organelles}}
•roles
{{c5::
bone resorption
signaling
}}

{{c1::compact}} bone
•dense
•located in the {{c2::peripheral}} part of a bone
•laid down in {{c3::osteons (Haversian systems)}}
series of concentric {{c4::lamellae}} with a canal containing blood vessels and nerves in the center
{{c4::lamellae}} are of three types:
{{c5::concentric (Haversian)}} – form the osteon itself
{{c6::interstitial}} – between osteons
{{c7::circumferential}} – around outside and inside of bone

{{c1::Compact}} bone
•{{c2::Periosteum}}
Connective tissue covering of bone
{{c3::Fibrous}} layer
{{c3::Osteogenic}} layer
•{{c2::Endosteum}}
Inner surface of bone, lining the marrow cavity
Formed of active osteoblasts or bone lining cells, and osteoclasts

{{c1::Spongy}} bone ({{c2::cancellous}} or {{c2::trabecular}} bone)
•Formed of interconnecting {{c3::trabeculae}}*
•Marrow spaces between {{c3::trabeculae}}
•{{c3::Trabeculae}} actually strengthen the bone because they diffuse stresses on the bone
* {{c3::trabecula}} = tissue element in the form of a small beam, strut or rod

The skull or {{c1::calvaria::another name}}
the bones of the skull have two external bony tables separated by {{c2::spongy}} bone, called {{c3::diploic}} bone ({{c3::diploë}})*
the periosteum of the skull is called {{c4::pericranium}}
New Latin, from Greek {{c3::diploē}}, from {{c3::diploos}} double

Marrow
•The cellular material occupying the spaces inside bone
{{c1::Red}} marrow
Consists of developing {{c2::blood}} cells
Contains {{c3::reticular}} cells and {{c3::reticular}} fibers
Has abundant sinusoids
{{c1::Yellow}} marrow
{{c4::Adipose}} tissue found within the medullary cavity
Replaces {{c5::red}} marrow as a person ages

{{c1::Sharpey’s}} fibers
•{{c2::Collagen}} fibers from the periosteum or from tendons or ligaments that become embedded in the bone matrix
•Fibers from the periodontal ligament that become embedded in cementum are also called {{c1::Sharpey’s}} fibers

Vitamins are essential to healthy bone
•Vitamin {{c1::C}} is required for {{c5::collagen}} formation.  In people with {{c3::scurvy}} (vitamin {{c1::C}} deficiency), bone matrix cannot be calcified
•Vitamin {{c2::D}} is necessary for {{c4::absorbing}} and {{c4::processing}} calcium, required for bone and tooth formation

Roles of hormones
•{{c1::PTH – parathyroid}} hormone
Secreted by {{c5::parathyroid}} glands
Stimulates bone {{c2::resorption}}, thus elevating blood {{c3::calcium}} levels
•{{c4::Calcitonin}}
Secreted by the {{c5::thyroid}} gland
Inhibits {{c6::osteoclast}} activity, and promotes urinary excretion of {{c7::calcium}} and {{c7::phosphate}}

Roles of hormones
•{{c1::Sex steroids}}
Promote bone growth during {{c2::adolescence}}
Prevent bone loss in {{c2::adulthood}}
